channel.title: NYT > Arts
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: How ‘The Traitors’ Builds Its Perfect Reality TV Cast
item.description: The casting executives behind the Emmy-winning reality competition reveal how they create a mad mix of modern celebrity.
item.dc:creator: Joe Coscarelli

item.title: ‘Wuthering Heights’ Review: Margot Robbie, Amok on the Moors
item.description: The actor and Jacob Elordi play the tortured lovers from the Emily Brontë classic in this florid, overstuffed version by Emerald Fennell.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: PEN America Names New Leadership After Gaza Fallout
item.description: After a 16-month search, the free speech group has chosen two longtime employees, Summer Lopez and Clarisse Rosaz Shariyf, as co-chief executives.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler

item.title: Taylor Stanley Makes Their Presence Known in NYCB’s ‘Sleeping Beauty’
item.description: Taylor Stanley debuts as Carabosse, the glamorous, evil fairy in “The Sleeping Beauty.” He is the first male-identifying person to take the role at New York City Ballet.
item.dc:creator: Gia Kourlas
item.media:credit: Guarionex Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taylor Stanley in the costume for Carabosse in “The Sleeping Beauty.”

item.title: Beethoven’s ‘Egmont,’ by Way of Cate Blanchett and Jeremy O. Harris
item.description: Gustavo Dudamel, Blanchett and Harris sit down to discuss their new version of Beethoven’s classic, premiering in Los Angeles this week.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney
item.media:credit: Jake Michaels for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left, Gustavo Dudamel, Cate Blanchett and Jeremy O. Harris at Walt Disney Concert Hall.

item.title: ‘Kramer/Fauci’ Revisits a Sparring Match During the AIDS Crisis
item.description: At the heart of Daniel Fish’s verbatim staging of a C-SPAN segment is a complex relationship, between Larry Kramer and Anthony Fauci, that “goes from ‘I hate you’ to ‘I love you’ and back.”
item.dc:creator: Juan A. Ramírez
item.category: Skirball Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Thomas Jay Ryan as Larry Kramer in “Kramer/Fauci,” a verbatim staging of the 1993 televised clash between Anthony Fauci, who was the nation’s leading AIDS researcher, and Kramer, the playwright and activist.

item.title: Improbably Famous, Then Perpetually Forgotten. Now, the Renaissance of Edmonia Lewis
item.description: A 19th-century sculptor of Black and Indigenous ancestry was acclaimed, then overlooked. But a groundswell of scholars and artists are keeping her flame alive in new projects.
item.dc:creator: Hilarie M. Sheets

item.title: ‘How to Get to Heaven From Belfast’: Lisa McGee Spins a Comedic Mystery
item.description: Lisa McGee said she had envisaged her new show, “How to Get to Heaven From Belfast,” as a sort of modern, funny “Murder, She Wrote.” Just don’t expect tired Irish stereotypes.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:description: Caoilfhionn Dunne, Roisin Gallagher and Sinead Keenan as the three protagonists of “How to Get to Heaven From Belfast.”

item.title: Looking at ‘The Goldfinch,’ and Thinking About Extinction
item.description: A new exhibition about birds ranges from old masters paintings to contemporary art. The show is “a mad sprawl of instincts and intuitions,” says its curator, Simon Schama.
item.dc:creator: Nina Siegal
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.media:description: “The Goldfinch” by Carel Fabritius is one of the collection treasures at the Mauritshuis museum in The Hague.

item.title: ‘The Monsters’ Review: A Redemptive Sibling Rivalry
item.description: Ngozi Anyanwu’s searing two-hander follows a brother and sister who train in boxing, side by side.
item.dc:creator: Brittani Samuel

item.title: ‘Good Luck, Have Fun, Don’t Die’ Review: Saving the World Again
item.description: Gore Verbinski returns with a weird, wild movie about stopping a rogue A.I., for the 117th time.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson
item.category: Good Luck, Have Fun, Don't Die (Movie)

item.title: ‘My Father’s Shadow’ Review: The Double Frame of Memory
item.description: Two sons accompany their father for the day in a poignant and bittersweet Nigerian debut film.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: Grand Theft Artifact? A New Game Asks Players to Steal Stolen Art.
item.description: Museum heists have a higher calling in Relooted, a video game where players take the repatriation of African artifacts into their own hands.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small

item.title: ‘Cold Storage’ Review: Liam Neeson vs. the Gross Green Threat
item.description: In this goofy B-movie throwback, it’s Liam Neeson to the rescue as a weary, tough-talking bioterror operative.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: ‘The Daily Show’ Gives President Trump Yet Another Inaugural Award
item.description: Jordan Klepper congratulated the president, the sole nominee for “the Inaugural Award for Winning the Most Inaugural Awards.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)

item.title: ‘The Unknown’ Review: Sean Hayes Turns One Man Into a Mystery
item.description: The chameleonic actor takes on several characters in David Cale’s solo play about a writer in pursuit of his stalker. Or is it all in his mind?
item.dc:creator: Helen Shaw
item.media:description: Sean Hayes in “The Unknown” at Studio Seaview in Manhattan.

item.title: ‘The Pitt’ Season 2, Episode 6 Recap: A Sudden Goodbye
item.description: A sudden death rattles the doctors and nurses at the Pitt a little more than usual. Meanwhile, the patients keep steaming in.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins
item.media:description: The bad first day back for Dr. Langdon (Patrick Ball) continued with the death of a beloved patient.

item.title: Greg Brown, Guitarist Who Wrote Cake’s Biggest Hit, Dies at 56
item.description: His song “The Distance,” released in 1996, became an anthem for the disaffected members of Generation X.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Mr. Brown in 1996. He left Cake after “Fashion Nugget,” partly over differences with the lead singer, John McCrea.

item.title: ‘Love Story’ Recreates a Tragic Romance
item.description: The series dramatizes the relationship between John F. Kennedy Jr. and Carolyn Bessette, who married in 1996 and died a few years later. Here’s what to know.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman
item.category: Love Story: John F. Kennedy Jr. & Carolyn Bessette (TV Program)

item.title: Helmuth Rilling, Who Recorded Huge Swaths of Bach, Dies at 92
item.description: He was the first to record all of J.S. Bach’s nearly 200 sacred cantatas, a project that stood out not only for its range but also for its steadfast style.
item.dc:creator: David Allen
item.media:description: Helmuth Rilling conducting Bach’s “St. Matthew Passion” at Carnegie Hall in 2007. His cycle of that composer’s nearly 200 surviving sacred cantatas engaged him from 1969 to 1985.

item.title: ‘Nirvanna the Band the Show the Movie’ Review: Canadian Fakin’
item.description: Two longtime friends time-travel back to 2008 to pursue their performing dreams in this likably daft comedy.
item.dc:creator: Jeannette Catsoulis
item.category: Nirvanna the Band the Show the Movie (Movie)

item.title: 5 Classical Music Albums You Can Listen to Right Now
item.description: Tyshawn Sorey’s tribute to the Rothko Chapel, a vintage Pavarotti concert and a release from the Berlin Philharmonic are among our selections.

item.title: ‘Scarlet’ Review: The Rest Is Anime
item.description: Mamoru Hosoda’s animated film about a fierce princess is a genderbent fantasy version of “Hamlet.”
item.dc:creator: Maya Phillips

item.title: ‘Goat’ Review: Stephen Curry’s Animated Basketball Debut
item.description: Stephen Curry lends his voice to this visually dynamic animated film that treats every basketball game like a roller coaster action set piece.
item.dc:creator: Brandon Yu

item.title: ‘Crime 101’ Review: Stealing Diamonds and Movie Ideas
item.description: Despite a solid cast and pedigree of its own, a Los Angeles crime saga borrows all its best moves from Michael Mann.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: ‘By Design’ Review: She’s Getting the Chair
item.description: Juliette Lewis plays a woman whose soul inhabits a bespoke armchair in Amanda Kramer’s cinematic specialty item.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Winkelman

item.title: Why Are So Many Artists Night Owls?
item.description: For some, creativity awakens after dark.
item.dc:creator: Hanya Yanagihara

item.title: New York Is Getting Sleepier. These Artists Are Wide Awake.
item.description: The city is going to bed earlier, but there are still those harnessing the creative power of the night.
item.dc:creator: Ligaya Mishan, Kate Guadagnino, Miguel Morales, Coco Romack and Richard Barnes

item.title: Jill Scott and Bisa Butler on Staying the Course
item.description: Ahead of the release of Scott’s first new album in over a decade, the musician and the artist discuss time-consuming art and the impulse to teach.
item.dc:creator: Niela Orr

item.title: Late Night Boos Pam Bondi’s ‘Bratty’ Behavior
item.description: “If downplaying international sex rings were an Olympic sport, Bondi would take home the gold,” Jordan Klepper said on “The Daily Show.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)

item.title: Turkish Nobel Novelist Orhan Pamuk Gets the Netflix Series He Wanted
item.description: After publishing more than 20 books and winning a Nobel Prize, the Turkish author fought to bring a celebrated novel to the screen — on his own terms.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Emin Ozmen
item.media:description: Orhan Pamuk in his office in Istanbul, in an apartment building named for his family.

item.title: Where to Stream ‘Varsity Blues’ and James Van Der Beek’s Best Performances
item.description: The actor seemed to understand early on that his lasting legacy would be the title character of “Dawson’s Creek.” But he found ways to subvert his all-American persona.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman

item.title: ‘The Other Place’: Tobias Menzies and Emma D’Arcy in a Psychosexual Sophocles Update
item.description: In Alexander Zeldin’s naturalistic adaptation of “Antigone,” Tobias Menzies and Emma D’Arcy star as a feuding uncle and niece.
item.dc:creator: Helen Shaw
item.media:description: The cast of “The Other Place,” from left: Lee Braithwaite, Emma D’Arcy, Ruby Stokes and Tobias Menzies at the Shed in Manhattan.

item.title: Artforum’s Top Editor Will Step Down
item.description: The magazine announced that two other editors there will jointly replace Tina Rivers Ryan, who has been in the role since 2024.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi

item.title: James Van Der Beek: The ‘Dawson’s Creek’ Star’s Life and Career in Photos
item.description: The actor was best known for his early roles in “Dawson’s Creek” and “Varsity Blues.”
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez

item.title: Bud Cort, Who Starred in 1971’s ‘Harold and Maude,’ Dies at 77
item.description: The role, one of his first, made him a household name and a film idol of the anti-establishment 1970s. But it also limited his growth as an actor.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Bud Cort as the teenager Harold Chasen who falls in love with a 79-year-old woman in Hal Ashby’s movie “Harold and Maude,” from 1971. Panned at first, it became a cult classic.

item.title: In His Second Act, James Van Der Beek Starred Online as a Proud Dad and Family Man
item.description: The actor, who died on Wednesday, was most famous for “Dawson’s Creek,” but as he got older, he let fans into his real life as a father of six.
item.dc:creator: Maya Salam
item.media:description: James Van Der Beek, who died on Wednesday, with two of his six children at a charity event in 2023.

item.title: Tamas Vasary, Pianist of Power and Sensitivity, Dies at 92
item.description: He bought technical brilliance and stylistic authority to Romantic-era music, particularly the works of Chopin and Liszt.
item.dc:creator: Tim Page
item.media:credit: Erich Auerbach/Hulton Archive, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Tamas Vasary around 1965. He was best known for his many recordings, most of them on the Deutsche Grammophon label.

item.title: Ken Peplowski, Who Helped Revive the Jazz Clarinet, Dies at 66
item.description: Also a saxophone standout, he served as stylistic bridge between the Benny Goodman swing era and the genre-blurring present.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Ken Peplowski in 2010 with the guitarist James Chirillo at the Lucille Lortel Theater in Manhattan. The musician and critic Russell Davies once called Mr. Peplowski “arguably the greatest living jazz clarinetist.”

item.title: LaMonte McLemore, Founding Singer With the 5th Dimension, Dies at 90
item.description: His group notched smooth hippie-era hits like “Up, Up and Away” and “The Age of Aquarius” in embracing a genre-blurring sound they called “champagne soul.”
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams
item.media:description: LaMonte McLemore, second from left, performing with the 5th Dimension on television in 1970. With him, from left, were Florence LaRue, Ron Townson, Billy Davis Jr. and Marilyn McCoo. From 1967 to 1973, the group notched 20 Top 40 singles.

item.title: Andrew Ranken, Whose Drumming Powered the Pogues, Dies at 72
item.description: Known as “The Clobberer,” he pounded out driving rhythms that fueled the band’s boisterous blend of traditional Irish music, rock and punk.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Andrew Ranken performing with the Pogues in Manchester, England, in 2013.

item.title: James Van Der Beek, ‘Dawson’s Creek’ Actor, Dies at 48 After Cancer Battle
item.description: He first appeared in a hit TV drama as a wide-eyed 15-year-old who then grew up over six seasons. He announced he had cancer in 2024.
item.dc:creator: Anita Gates
item.media:description: James Van Der Beek in 2002. His character in “Dawson’s Creek” knew, as he put it, the “unyielding, merciless torture” of unrequited love.

item.title: In the Sci-Fi World of ‘Arco’, It’s About ‘Respecting Kids’ Intelligence’
item.description: The Oscar-nominated “Arco” aims to give viewers of all ages hope in the possibility of a brighter tomorrow.
item.dc:creator: Carlos Aguilar
item.media:description: A still from “Arco,” in which two children from different eras come together through time travel.

item.title: In ‘Soul Power,’ a Fresh Look at the League That Helped Launch Dr. J
item.description: Executive produced by Julius Erving, a new docuseries tells the story of the A.B.A., birthplace of the 3-pointer, slam-dunk contest and a lot of style.
item.dc:creator: Stuart Miller
item.category: Soul Power: The Legend of the American Basketball Association (TV Program)

item.title: Decades of Palestinian History, Told by 3 Films With Awards Hopes
item.description: “The Voice of Hind Rajab,” “All That’s Left of You” and “Palestine 36” each tries to unpack the complex lives of Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: Sara Aridi

item.title: The Book Jackets Were Ready. Then Charlie Kirk Was Shot.
item.description: What’s a publisher to do when a novel hews close to the news cycle?
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth A. Harris
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by The New York Times
item.media:description: The covers of the advance reader and finished copies of “Murder Bimbo,” by Rebecca Novack.

item.title: Mike Tirico Went From the Super Bowl to the Olympics on Two Cups of Coffee
item.description: As the veteran NBC sportscaster worked the Super Bowl on Sunday, he had his bags ready to go. Soon after the final whistle, a private jet whisked him to Italy.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan
item.media:description: “Let’s enjoy this,” one of Mike Tirico’s producers told him about covering the Super Bowl in California and the Winter Olympics in Italy.

item.title: Can Artists Help Shape American Cities Again?
item.description: Artists have played a vital role in defining the American city only to be forced out when rents rise. A novel approach in San Francisco seeks to break the cycle.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small and Ian C. Bates
item.media:description: Inside a duplex that has been donated to a trust helping artists afford housing in the Bay Area. A muralist, Juancarlos Sagastume, painted the wall in 2005.

item.title: Late Night Mines Trump’s Million Mentions in the Epstein Files
item.description: “A million times? There’s not even that many references to Hamlet in the play ‘Hamlet,’” Jordan Klepper said on “The Daily Show.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)

item.title: Timothée Chalamet, Teyana Taylor and Jacob Elordi at the Oscar Nominees Luncheon
item.description: At the Oscar nominees’ luncheon, Timothée Chalamet, Teyana Taylor and Jacob Elordi mingled with documentarians and behind-the-scenes professionals.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan, Sinna Nasseri and Sela Shiloni
item.category: Come See Me in the Good Light (Movie)
item.media:credit: Sinna Nasseri for The New York Times
item.media:description: When Perfidia met Frankenstein’s monster: Teyana Taylor and Jacob Elordi.

item.title: Britney Spears Sells Her Song Catalog
item.description: The pop hitmaker, who hasn’t released a new album in 10 years, sold the rights to her music to Primary Wave.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario
item.media:description: Britney Spears has sold tens of millions of albums and scored five No. 1 hits on Billboard’s Hot 100 singles chart.

item.title: Bad Bunny’s Super Bowl Halftime Show and the Everyday People Who Made It Authentic
item.description: A priest from Sacramento. A bar owner from New York. A taquero from Los Angeles. Puerto Rico came alive at the Super Bowl because of hundreds of non-famous performers.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor

item.title: Hudson Talbott Dies at 76; Wrote and Illustrated Wide-Ranging Children’s Books
item.description: His book about time-traveling dinosaurs became a Steven Spielberg-produced movie, and he adapted the Stephen Sondheim musical “Into the Woods” for young readers.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

item.title: Gabor Boritt, Refugee Who Became Expert on Lincoln, Dies at 86
item.description: He survived the Holocaust and Communist rule in Hungary, arrived penniless in New York and made himself into a pre-eminent Civil War scholar.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.category: Gilder Lehrman Institute of American History
item.media:description: Gabor Boritt in 2006. At Gettysburg College in Pennsylvania, near the site of the 1863 battle that changed the course of the Civil War, he built a career around Abraham Lincoln.

item.title: 13 Transcendent Beatles Covers by Black Musicians
item.description: Listen to how Tina Turner, Al Green, Beyoncé and others reinterpreted, revised and reimagined the Fab Four.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Zoladz
item.media:credit: Charlie Gates for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tina Turner

item.title: ‘Galileo’ Musical, Starring Raúl Esparza, Will Open on Broadway
item.description: The musical, called “Galileo,” will star Raúl Esparza, and is scheduled to open in December at the Shubert Theater.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson

item.title: Chappell Roan Leaves Casey Wasserman Agency Over Epstein Files
item.description: Casey Wasserman, who founded and leads the talent agency bearing his name, exchanged flirtatious emails with Ghislaine Maxwell in the early 2000s.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Chappell Roan at the 2026 Grammy Awards.

item.title: Philippe Gaulier, Clown Who Taught Actors Like Sacha Baron Cohen, Dies at 82
item.description: He often insulted his pupils, but many became stars, including Sacha Baron Cohen, Emma Thompson and Rachel Weisz.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall

item.title: In ‘Love Story,’ Sarah Pidgeon Has Big Stilettos to Fill
item.description: Playing Carolyn Bessette-Kennedy, the actress faced a backlash before filming even finished. She “had to just keep betting on myself and what my instincts were.”
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski and Caroline Tompkins
item.category: Love Story: John F. Kennedy Jr. & Carolyn Bessette (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Caroline Tompkins for The New York Times

item.title: Inside Danny L Harle’s Synthetic Universe
item.description: On his new solo album, “Cerulean,” the hyperpop producer who’s worked with Dua Lipa and Caroline Polachek explores his own sonic byways.
item.dc:creator: Jon Pareles
item.media:credit: Sam Dearden for The New York Times
item.media:description: Since the early 2010s, Danny L Harle has released more than 100 tracks, but he considers “Cerulean” his first full-fledged solo album.

item.title: What Happens in a Performer’s Brain While Playing Music?
item.description: The pianist Nicolas Namoradze teamed with neuroscientists for a breakthrough in experiment design.
item.dc:creator: Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times
item.media:description: The pianist Nicolas Namoradze wanted to record videos that would visualize how his brain activity changed as he played music with different moods and structures.

item.title: The Artist Nick Cave Couches His Critique in Dazzle
item.description: For “Mammoth,” a new show at the Smithsonian American Art Museum, he takes up contentious issues of race and climate change in beads, sequins and Lite-Brite colors.
item.dc:creator: Blake Gopnik and Donavon Smallwood
item.media:description: The artist Nick Cave at his exhibition “Mammoth” at the Smithsonian American Art Museum. Behind a bounty of beads he recognizes that his topical show might yet face pushback.
